Health & Safety for Licensed Child Care Providers, Module C
Section 3: Emergency Preparedness, Response & Recovery

Practice

Now we have worked with local officials, developed our plan, and communicated the plan to parents. But we don’t stop now. We must Practice.

  • Training - New, Ongoing, & Individualized

    All new hires must receive general training on emergency preparedness. All child care providers and volunteers also receive ongoing training as part of the federal and state requirements. Emergency Preparedness focuses on training providers on the preparation, response and recovery of all types of emergencies in child care settings. In addition to this all staff must be trained on the child care facility’s Emergency Plan. Those involved with caring for infants and toddlers, children with special needs, and children with chronic medical conditions must also receive training on the unique needs of those children.

  • Drills - All Types of Disasters

    Next comes drills. LARA requires fire drills quarterly and tornado drills twice per year. In addition to this staff should go through drills for each type of emergency discussed in the plan. Drills must happen during hours that children are being cared for.

  • Review and Update Plan

    The Emergency Plan should be reviewed and updated bi-annually and after each emergency.

Emergency situations are not conducive to calm and composed thinking. A written plan offers the opportunity to prepare. Drills and practice offer the insurance that when an emergency hits the child care provider can respond in a more calm and organized manner.
